passages.text: Hong Kong | Insurance
Equity Research August 28, 2025

1H 2025 results further reinforced our view that AIA's sales will continue to surprise consensus and that management's Operating Profit After Tax (OPAT) targets will be exceeded. Moreover, we were struck by the ongoing inflexion in the Return on Embedded Value (ROEV), which rose again (to \(17.8\%\) ), a fact that we believe is completely at odds with the current Price to Embedded Value multiple implied by AIA's share price.

Beyond Recovery - Since the Hong Kong border reopened in early 2023, investor attention has honed in the apparent disconnect between a share price derating and recovery in new sales. As of 1H 2025, this disconnect has entered a new phase, because with the ROEV now at \(17.8\%\) , AIA's profitability is no longer recovering but hitting a new high. The Value of New Business (VONB) is also up \(+16\%\) at constant FX, confounding concerns that AIA is "only a \(+10\%\) growth company". Whereas it was once possible to dismiss elevated growth as a recovery on a pandemic- impacted base (VONB grew \(+33\%\) in 2023), the same does not apply today, in our view, as continued VONB growth of \(+16\%\) in 1H 2025 comes on top of \(+18\%\) in 2024.

The Value Gap - However, such strong fundamental recovery has not translated into AIA's share price performance. Charts in this note reveal how unusual this is, because though the shares reliably re- rated in advance of profitability improving between the IPO (2010) and the Hong Kong reopening (2023), this correlation has since collapsed. Today, the shares trade at just \(1.5x\) P/EV, and while this is substantially above the all- time low of \(1.0x\) (April 2024), it remains below the 5- year average of \(1.7x\) , the post- IPO average of \(1.8x\) , and the all- time high of \(2.6x\) (January 2021). Moreover, if the previous correlation with AIA's profitability reasserted itself, the implied multiple could be \(2.7x\) .

New Normal or Mean Reversion - Thus, on the one hand, AIA's track record implies that the stock is deeply undervalued, while on the other, the derating of the past two- and- a- half years arguably meets the definition of a "new normal". To some extent, it all depends on the lens through which it is viewed, because while AIA's shares are up \(+31\%\) year- to- date, they have also materially underperformed Prudential, up \(+64\%\) . Furthermore, though AIA has recently re- rated from \(1.0x\) P/EV to \(1.5x\) , this multiple remains below the high reached in the summer of 2024, when Hong Kong listed equities rallied on expectations of government stimulus.

Maintaining our Multiple - Amidst this debate, we have maintained our target multiple of \(1.55x\) , implying \(+17\%\) upside (inclusive of dividends), prompting us to reiterate our Buy recommendation. However, we acknowledge that a higher multiple could be justified if the market can be reassured of the regional macroeconomic and geopolitical risks. In terms of forecast, mark- to- market impacts drive EPS, while the underlying movements in operating profit are immaterial.
Please see analyst certifications, important disclosure information, and information regarding the status of non-US analysts on pages 10 - 15 of this report. \\* Jefferies International Limited

- AIA's professional agency network gives the group an advantage over domestic peers in South East Asia- AIA's product mix focus on health, protection, and unit-linked optimises both risk and margins (i.e., underweight guaranteed savings)- We believe that the depth of AIA's expertise in China and their long-term biometric data (collected over a century of underwriting) gives the group unique insights that will enable faster growth, with less risk- AIA's wholly owned subsidiary in the Chinese Life Insurance market is a competitive advantage to other foreign life insurers- Malaysian market growth is overlooked by consensus, AIA is taking share in Singapore, and there has been a flight to quality in Thailand
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View

- AIA continues to report favourable operating variances to the group's embedded value assumptions, prompting the market to value the back book with a c.1.0x P/EV multiple- Having surpassed the 2018 high point for Hong Kong premiums in 2024, we now expect new policy sales to be surpassed in 2026- Traditional and Takaful sales in Malaysia rise with accelerating insurance penetration- Bond yields and interest rates remain stable- Excess capital funds buybacks- Cost of Equity of 17.9%- Growth Rate of 3.3%- SOTP Price Target of HK\$85

- AIA continues to report favourable operating variances to the group's embedded value assumptions, prompting the market to value the back book with a c.1.1x P/EV multiple, thereby valuing favourable development that is yet to be reported- Hong Kong's cross-border new policy volumes rebound to pre-pandemic levels faster than expected- Bond yields and interest rates slowly rise- Excess capital higher than expected- Cost of Equity of 15.0%- Growth Rate of 4.0%- SOTP Price Target of HK\$105

- AIA starts to report unfavourable operating variances to the group's embedded value assumptions, prompting the market to value the back book with a c.0.6x P/EV multiple, thereby valuing a deficit yet to be recognised- Hong Kong's competitive position is impaired- Thai competitors recover from the pandemic and erode AIA's market share- Bond yields and interest rates slowly fall- Excess capital retained and not valued- Cost of Equity of 21.0%- Growth Rate of 2.0%- SOTP Price Target of HK\$50

Top Material Issue(s), Policies designed to incentivise responsible behaviour. AIA's Health and Protection products perform better when its customers live longer and have healthier lives. Thus, AIA is incentivised to promote a healthy lifestyle amongst its customers. AIA Vitality offers customers financial rewards for improving their fitness, as well as providing tailored health and well-being advice. 2) Incorporation of ESG Factors in Investment Management. AIA can have a positive impact via their proprietary investments and investing client money.

Company Target(s): 1) Net Zero emissions by 2050. 2) Target of engaging One Billion people by 2030. 3) 100% of in- scope investee companies will establish Science- Based Targets for their organisations by 2040.

Questions to Management: 1) How do your products incentivise responsible customer behaviour? 2) What percentage of your investment portfolio do you intend to allocate to ESG assets and funds? 3) How is your investment portfolio resilient to economic downturns?

- Volume of traffic across the China and Hong Kong border- Improving economic forecasts could lift the level of disposable income and savings rates, driving asset inflows- Rising bond yields and interest rates would be favourable for future spread income but will result in near-term mark-to-market volatility and may prompt changes in persistency rates- Financial market volatility could negatively impact the valuation of the investments

Valuation of AIAOur 12- month price target is HKD 85.00, valuing AIA on 1.54x 2025F Price- to- Embedded Value.
We set the Cost of Equity by country with, starting with a \(10\%\) base.

Mainland China at \(22.0\%\) \((+200ps\) for long duration, \(+200bps\) for competition, \(+300bps\) for regulation, and \(+500bps\) for economic risk) Hong Kong at \(22.0\%\) \((+200bps\) for long duration, \(+500bps\) for economic risk and \(+500bps\) for regulation) Thailand at \(11.0\%\) \((+200bps\) for long- duration, \(- 100bps\) to reflect AIA's distribution advantage) Singapore at \(12.0\%\) \((+200bps\) for long- duration) Malaysia at \(12.0\%\) \((+200bps\) for long- duration) Other Markets at \(15.0\%\) \((+200bps\) for long- duration, \(+500bps\) for frontier market risk, \(- 200bps\) to reflect its diversification)
Combined, this gives AIA a weighted average Cost of Equity of \(17.9\%\)
We set the Long- Term Growth Rate by country with:

Mainland China at \(4.0\%\) , reduced from \(6.0\%\) to reflect the slowdown in the Chinese economy Hong Kong at \(3.0\%\) to reflect the expected dynamic of limited domestic growth (residents have already purchased cover), but elevated recently to capture the reopening rebound, which we expect to remain elevated due to macroeconomic pressures in Mainland China Thailand at \(2.5\%\) to reflect the ongoing boom in sales for insurers not impacted by the COVID- 19 sales crisis Singapore at \(2.5\%\) to reflect the market's maturity, which is offset by AIA's growing market share Malaysia at \(4.0\%\) to reflect the market being close to the industry growth inflection point Other Markets at \(4.0\%\) to reflect the nascent size of the industry in many emerging Asian economies
Combined, this gives AIA a weighted average Long- Term Growth Rate of \(3.3\%\)

When considering the locked- in value of AIA's back book of existing business, a key feature that determines our view is the Embedded Value operating variances. These assumptions have consistently been revised favourably, demonstrating the group's long- term actuarial prudence. This prompts us to value the back book at \(1.0xP / EV\) , as this reflects the full locked- in value, but prudently does not ascribe any value to the likely revisions. If AIA were to consistently or materially revise these assumptions unfavourably, this would negatively impact our view of the group and could prompt us to consider a back book multiple that is below \(1.0xP / EV\) .

When assessing the front book we use the cost of equity and growth rate assumptions previously noted to establish a P/E multiple equivalent with which to price the Value of New Business (VONB). Given the relatively high long- term growth rates, we value the VONB of AIA's growth in most countries at a mid- teens multiple, despite using high risk premiums.

Risk FactorsBelow we summarise a few of the principal risks relating to AIA. Inspiration for the list below comes from the 2010 IPO document, supplemented by our knowledge of subsequent events, concerns at peers, and industry- wide factors.

Market Risks- As a life insurer, AIA is inherently subject to market fluctuations and general economic conditions- Foreign exchange risk is inevitable given that AIA currently operates in 18 different markets- Interest rate changes may adversely impact the balance sheet, earnings, and cash flow- Exact matching of asset and liability duration is not possible, exacerbating interest rate exposure- Solvency could be impacted by mark- to- market losses, credit downgrades, defaults, and impairments- Liquidity could be impacted by the failure of investments to yield the expected cash flows- Access and availability of credit from debt capital markets may limit the group's financial flexibility- Changing financial markets may change customer behaviour, impacting persistency and sales

Regulation and Credit Rating Risks- Opinions of credit rating agencies are relevant for raising debt capital, persistency of in- force business, and new sales- Regulatory changes and government restrictions may impact access to key markets- Local regulations may impact the capital efficiency of the group and its ability to balance risks internationally- Limits on global reinsurance and cash remittance may limit the group's ability to operate across borders- Litigation could lead to material adverse outcomes- Changing taxation is relevant for persistency and sales of life insurance and savings

Competition Risks- Competition from banks via savings products or bancassurance may impact persistency, sales, and margins- Competition from life insurers with protection products or savings may impact persistency, sales, and margins- AIA depends on its ability to attract, employ, train, and retain sufficient numbers of high- quality employees and agents- Although the average wage of life insurance agents and employees is more than twice the local average salary, rising wage inflation in other sectors could dissuade applicants from entering the industry

Operational Risks- Differences between the pricing models and actual claims and benefit experience could lead to unfavourable variances- Epidemics, pandemics, natural catastrophes, terrorism, and war may all impact health, mortality, and longevity unfavourably- Epidemics, pandemics, natural catastrophes, terrorism, and war may all impact investments unfavourably- AIA's brand and reputation are critical to the persistency of in- force business, new sales, and relations with key stakeholders- Employee or agent misconduct or mis- selling is difficult to deter and detect (although technology is reducing this)- Data protection regulation and the risk of failing to comply could have a negative impact on AIA's finances or reputation- Availability and legality of the use of data could impact the group's ability to price its products- Disruption to distribution relationships may impact persistency and new sales- Disruption to third- party service suppliers may impact the group internally or the services provided externally

AIA is the largest, independent, publicly listed, pan- Asian life insurance group. Founded in Shanghai in 1919, AIA underwrites life, accident and health insurance, as well as offering retirement planning, wealth management and savings contracts.

We prudently value the back book at c.1x P/EV, reflecting the group's extensive track record of favourably revising its Embedded Value assumptions. We value the front book by geography, applying a P/VONB multiple derived from the local cost of equity and terminal growth rate. Upside potential comes from faster growth in Asian GDP per capita. Downside risks come from sales restrictions and local competition.

We prudently value the back book at c.1x P/EV, reflecting the group's extensive track record of favourably revising its Embedded Value assumptions. We value the front book by geography, applying a P/VONB multiple derived from the local cost of equity and terminal growth rate. Upside potential comes from faster growth in Asian GDP per capita. Downside risks come from sales restrictions and local competition.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR)
Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed
Jefferies Financial Group Inc., its affiliates or subsidiaries make a market in the securities or ADRs of Prudential Plc.

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies' methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise PicksJefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
